person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_348.name: JanIngenhousz
person_348.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

person_376.name: ArmandSeguin
person_376.description: French chemist. He took over the editorial duties of the Annals de Chimie after Lavoisier's execution in 1794

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_227.name: JeanSenebier
person_227.description: Genevan naturalist; pioneer in field of photosynthesis.

person_029.name: ThomasBeddoes
person_029.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

person_471.name: WilliamHarvey
person_471.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_378.name: Jan RudolphDeiman
person_378.description: Dutch-German physician and chemist who examined the electrolysis of water and the application of electricity for medical purposes

person_379.name: Adriaan Paets vanTroostwijk
person_379.description: Dutch chemist who was a colleague of Deiman and between them they founded what would become the Society of Dutch Chemists

person_385.name: Samuel LathamMitchill
person_385.description: American chemist, botanist, natural historian and botanist, who studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh. He claimed nitrous oxide was poisonous (which Davy proved was wrong).

person_027.name: IsaacMilner
person_027.description: Mathematician and inventor. President of Queens' College, Cambridge, and Lucasian Professor of Mathematics. FRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_329.name: Thomas (Tom)Wedgwood
person_329.description: Youngest son of Josiah Wedgwood who became a close friend of Davy's. Together they published a paper which has been taken as marking the start of chemical photography.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_271.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
person_271.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

person_382.name: Joseph LouisProust
person_382.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

person_367.name: GeorgeHandel
person_367.description: German-born composer who spent much of his life in Britain, and was buried in Westminster Abbey.

person_479.name: WilliamCoates
person_479.description: Member of a family of Bristol wine merchants, visitor to the Medical Pneumatic Institution, and subscriber to various Bristol literary works. Later detained in France following the end of the Peace of Amiens.

person_236.name: WilliamNicholson
person_236.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

person_683.name: EdmundGoodwyn
person_683.description: Physician who studied with Thomas Beddoes at the University of Edinburgh.

person_052.name: GeorgePearson
person_052.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

person_141.name: Jean-AntoineChaptal
person_141.description: French chemist, physician and industrialist. ForMemRSL.

person_386.name: EvangelistaTorrecelli
person_386.description: Italian natural philosopher and mathematician who invented the barometer. He was a student of Galileo.

person_328.name: JohnAbernethy
person_328.description: English surgeon and medical lecturer working in London. FRSL.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_784.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
person_784.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_389.name: Pierre JosephMacquer
person_389.description: French chemist who published his Dictionnaire de Chymie in 1766 and later opposed Lavoisier's theories.

person_549.name: JamesKeir
person_549.description: Scottish-born chemist and industrial chemist who worked in the Midlands. Experimented with Joseph Priestley on gases in the 1780s and translated Macquer's 1766 Dictionnaire de chymie, published in 1771 and 1778 as the Dictionary of Chemistry. FRSL.

person_544.name: ImmanuelKant
person_544.description: Professor of Logic and Metaphysics at the University of Königsberg. Regarded as the most important philosopher of the eighteenth century.

person_018.name: DavidHartley
person_018.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

place_444.name: Tintern Abbey
place_444.description: Tintern Abbey is a ruin found on the banks of the River Wye in Monmouthshire, Wales. It was the location of a poem by William Wordsworth, published in Lyrical Ballads, the second edition of which was proof-read by Davy.

place_118.name: River Wye
place_118.description: The River Wye is the fourth-longest river in the UK, stretching from its source on Plynlimon in mid-Wales to the Severn Estuary. For much of its length the river forms part of the border between England and Wales.

place_579.name: Palmyra
place_579.description: Palmyra is an ancient city in the eastern part of the Levant, now in the centre of modern Syria.

place_645.name: Medical Pneumatic Institution
place_645.description: By 1798, located in 6-7 Dowry Square, Hotwells, Clifton, Bristol. Davy was employed by Thomas Beddoes to work as its Superindendent.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_419.name: Mount's Bay
place_419.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_006.name: Penzance
place_006.description: Penzance is a town, civil parish, and port in the Penwith district of Cornwall, and Davy's birthplace.

otherwork_125.name: Abrege des Principaux Phenomenes qui Dependent de l'Action du Calorique
otherwork_125.author: Armand Jean François Séguin
